My dad came up here on kind of a lark.

He was working in Los Angeles in 1905, and he and his buddy read the ad in the Los Angeles Times that they were opening up a new town in Las Vegas, and they were auctioning off lots, and you could take a round-trip to Las Vegas and stay overnight for $23 or whatever it was, and so they thought, well, that'd be a good, nice couple of days.

And so because of the store, he would go out there quite frequently, and he used to take my sister and myself with him, and the fellow that ran the store, he and his wife lived in the back of the store, and he was a security guard at the construction site, so he would tell my dad what areas were available, and so we used to go down and watch them do the work.

And the thing that was probably most unique about my experience was that they had to build cofferdams to dry up the dam construction area.

And so for several years, it was all dry, but when they got time to let the water start coming in, they'd been diverting the water through tunnels, diversion tunnels that had been created in the sides of the canyon.
That was a tremendous project in itself.
But the water had been diverted and then it came time, the dam was ready to meet the test of having water come up against the face of the dam.
So not too long--just about a week before the water got up high enough, they closed off the diversion tunnels and then, of course, the water began to rise on the upstream side.

And so my dad drove his car clear down in the bottom o--next to the upstream side of the dam, and my sister and I got out of the car and went over and touched the bottom of the dam, which is now roughly about 600 feet underwater.
